data.title: Really really long lines cut off first few characters when wrapped with cursor at end of line
data.body:
So with a really long line of text, if you put your cursor at the end:

![Screen Shot 2013-01-17 at 1 42 12 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/76425/34388fac-60ef-11e2-8d0c-9d34969e8fb6.png)

And then turn on soft wrapping:

![Screen Shot 2013-01-17 at 1 42 31 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/76426/3d12f252-60ef-11e2-8493-736c4a239351.png)

The resulting wrap actually cuts off the first couple of characters of the soft-wrapped lines, as if the user had scrolled to the right slightly:

![Screen Shot 2013-01-17 at 1 42 57 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/76428/6066fdca-60ef-11e2-8c7e-cc49f485749e.png)

Note that the very first couple of words on this line are "I went on to...". So the "I", the space, and the very start of the "w" glyph are actually put behind the gutter.

If you take the exact same long line of text without soft-wrapping enabled, but place the cursor at the beginning of the line:

![Screen Shot 2013-01-17 at 1 43 11 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/76444/a322c9d2-60ef-11e2-9a03-448b84463590.png)

And then trigger the same soft-wrap command, you wind up with no overlap. All the initial characters of the soft-wrapped lines are shown as they should be:

![Screen Shot 2013-01-17 at 1 43 21 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/76449/cf1fee5c-60ef-11e2-857d-50583a2f0898.png)

data.title: Allow tree view sidebar to be resized.
data.body:
Currently, the sidebar width is determined by the width of its content. So if you close a very wide directory, the sidebar shrinks, and whatever code you're looking at jumps on the page. This PR allows drag and drop resizing.

![resize-demo](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/483/76256/a68ff89a-60e7-11e2-9664-c795afd0f6ea.gif)
## Issues
- [x] If you drag too fast, the names of your tabs get highlighted
- [x] The size of the window is off by 12px because of padding in the tree view
- [x] The resize area is very small so it's easy to miss.
- [x] The behavior/styles are being applied to the package browser

data.title: nunemaker wishlist
data.body:
The biggest ones are selection and textmate snippets completing correctly (mentioned in bugs).
### selection
- [x] cmd + ctl + up/down moves line or selected lines up/down
- [x] how to map multiple selection like ctl + shft + up/down in sublime
- [ ] how to select same word that is found over and over, cmd + d in sublime
### bugs or expectations different
- [ ] **critical** "mod<tab>" completed to this http://cl.ly/MD2A, expected module … end, same thing with all the textmate snippets like "cla<tab>" for class ... end, and "do<tab>" for blocks
- [ ] escape does not close the search area, you have to focus input and hit escape
- [ ] cmd + w only works if focused in editor, expected active tab to close
- [x] cmd + ctl + f to move into and out of full screen support
- [ ] tree view active, cmd + p, search "file", nothing shows for new file, creating file, add file, same with directory and move file/directory, have to type "add" which wasn't my first thought
- [x] type {}, then backspace open brace, closing brace hangs around, i would expect it to go away
- [ ] some kind of more sane default window size, right now it is taller than wide, seems better to do wider than tall
### getting things done
- [ ] right click in tree view to create new file/dir, rename file/dir, move file/dir, etc. right click on dir creates file in dir
- [x] go to symbol (ctags) doesn't have space between method name and class name
- [ ] select a file in tree view without mouse/arrowing, maybe fuzzy find? you can do a lot once file selected, would be nice to select without using mouse
### moving around
- [ ] cmd + left goes to beginning of line, skipping whitespace, would love if it went to start of actual code and then as you kept hitting it toggled between beginning of line and beginning of code in line
- [x] option + left/right in sublime hops past spaces and to beginning/end of next word, atom hops to word, then space, then word, which forces 2x as many actions to move by "word"
- [x] join next line with the current line (cmd + j in sublime)
### editing
- [ ] autocomplete with ctl + spacebar is slow, sublime autocompletes all the time automatically, at first it was annoying but now I find it hard to maneuver without it, at a minimum tab auto-completing would be fantastic
- [x] hold command and hit backspace continues to backspace, stops in atom
- [x] auto add a new line to end of file on save if not already there (add `"stripTrailingWhitespace":{"singleTrailingNewline": true}` to your config)
- [ ] column_family({<enter>}) never gets indention correct for the })
- [x] duplicate current line with single key combo and set cursor at same point in new line as it was in original line (cmd + shift + d in sublime)
### projects
- [ ] all state is saved, including dirtiness, but not to actual file, rather to some other place, even unsaved files are restored across restarts and project switches
- [ ] projects, switch projects (cmd + ctl + p in sublime), remembers tabs across project switches, restore window size per project
### dreams
- [ ] terminal up this dude SO BAD PLZ
- [ ] hella fast start up, for things like using it as git commit editor
- [ ] realtime pairing like screen + ssh, but with atom...

data.title: Compile extension
data.body:
WIP
- [ ] specs
- [ ] proof of concept ruby test package using this base

This extension should act as a base to "extend" for other compilation extensions.
The idea is inspired by the Emacs compile-mode and similar utilities.

Example theoretical usage:

```
Compile = require('compile')

module.exports =
class RubyTest extends Compile
  compileCommand: ->
    'bin/rspec'

# maybe some automated binding to the same key regular Compile would use?
```

Maybe this should just be a library in the stdlib?

Kinda want to hear thoughts on this approach.

data.title: Add ability to bootstrap themes and packages from the atom cli
data.body:
It would be great to have a quick way to generate a basic template for packages and themes from the atom cli.

``` command-line
$ atom bootstrap --package --name=MyPackage
```

This could generate the basic structure for a packages and export the top-level module in your index.coffee file. 

``` command-line
$ atom bootstrap --theme --name=MyTheme
```

This could generate the basis for a theme which contains all the proper theme files with empty selectors for every piece of atom.

data.title: Consider using nak instead of ack
data.body:
Ok, so I'm sitting in Summit and blown the :shit: away by what you guys just showed. The funny thing is, after leaving Cloud9, I toyed with the idea of creating my own text editor with another friend.

Tangential to all that, I wrote my own Find-in-files/search-files module written in Node.js. It's heavily inspired by ack (which you're using) and ag. And it's fast as all hell: https://github.com/gjtorikian/nak (benchmarks available at the bottom) My ultimate goal was to be faster than ack, which I succeed by a large magnitude. 

The tool is _so badass_ that it's also touted on the official ack page: http://betterthangrep.com/more-tools/

At Cloud9, I worked on the backend search implementation, and here's the (long-winded!) discussion on how I moved from ack (in Perl) to ag (in C) to nak (in Node.js): https://github.com/ajaxorg/cloud9/pull/2369

If this is something you're interested in using for 0.1, I'll make the PR for the code.

data.title: Auto-indent config
data.body:
This adds two config options (default settings shown below)

``` coffeescript
editor:
  autoIndent: true
  autoIndentOnPaste: false
```

We use TextMate grammars to predict the appropriate indentation level. 

`editor.autoIndent` will use use this indentation level when you insert a newline or when you press tab on at the beginning of a line.

`editor.autoIndentOnPaste` will using the predicted indentation level to indent pasted text (duh.)

These config options can be toggle by the commands `window.auto-indent` and `window:auto-indent-on-paste`

data.title: Load snippets from packages and TextMate bundles
data.body:
This PR loads snippets out of packages and TextMate bundles, and it also takes some further steps toward making the snippets system TextMate-compatible by supporting nested snippet tab stops. There are still some missing features and incompatibilities with TextMate snippets, which I intend to address after the `0.1` release:
- There are unknown bugs with tab stop jumping in the coffeescript class snippet (and maybe others)
- Complex TextMate scope selectors involving `|` and `-` are not translated correctly to CSS
- When nested tab stops are destroyed, undo does not restore them cleanly
- TextMate variables / shell interpolation doesn't work (this might not be something we do anytime soon)
